posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked:
NOMAD CAD Release 2025  

FRC Team 6995 is proud to present the CAD for our 2025 Robot: Mariana!  

We utilized Onshape for detailed modeling and Behind the Bumpers for additional resources.  

Our new hand design enhances performance by allowing coral collection on both sides of the robot during levels 3 and 4. This improvement aims to increase cycle efficiency to an average of 4-5 cycles per match. Special thanks to 9442 and 8033 for their assistance.  

Additionally, we upgraded our hook climber to improve reliability, reducing climbing times from 15 seconds to between 5 and 7 seconds.  

Please feel free to reach out here with any questions or comments—we’re happy to assist!

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked: This robot is one of the cleanest ones that I have seen this year. Congrats on an amazing season and hoping to see you all make Einstein!

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: This is such a cool robot—a bad pun indeed! Is "nocad" a thing?

posts.name: waialua3:59
posts.cooked: The iteration throughout the season looks great! Good luck in your division, twin.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: I see you're considering a motorized wheel cage grabber. However, you're opting for one pole instead of two. How is this choice working out? Is there a specific reason for choosing single over dual?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: The single pole grabber was constructed for our Week 3 event but wasn’t utilized due to its limitations. Initially, it stood perpendicular to the elevator, causing difficulty in securing the pipe and failing to lower the eye bolt sufficiently to lift us off the ground. To address this, we adjusted an existing structure by angling it upward by 12 degrees, enabling it to operate outside the bumper and pull the eye bolt an additional inch or more downward. This modification improved its effectiveness.

posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked: We chose the single pole design over the dual pole because during testing, we observed that slamming into the cage from any angle would nearly always result in grabbing a corner, thereby reducing the need to wait for alignment before driving.

posts.name: waialua3:59
posts.cooked: We have something similar. We can tell you that a motorized set of wheels looking for a single pole works much easier and faster to lock into the cage; even when the cage is swinging, it remains just as quick.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: This concept may end up on our off-season bot Thanks for the insight

posts.name: Gabriel McMahon
posts.cooked:
Love the design! Your brainpan design is pretty different from others I've seen; how easy is it to access when in a rush?

Additionally, I also notice a lot of 3D prints around your pivot, what filament are you using, and have you had any trouble with pieces breaking?

posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked:
Accessing the electronics under the robot requires flipping it sideways and unscrewing the polycarbonate cover on the bottom, a few bolts before the rivnuts. This typically takes around 30 seconds once completed, after which we can proceed with our repairs or assembly.

The 3D printed components on the pivot utilize PLA proper (I think), and none have experienced any issues so far. Their role is primarily as spacers or to apply axial constraints rather than bearing any structural load.

posts.name: Bpk9p4
posts.cooked: That's a really cool robot! I was checking out your CAD file, but I wasn't entirely sure how your friction brake works. Maybe you can explain it a bit more.
It was awesome watching this bot cook on Einstein. How do you deal with backlash when many gear reductions on the pivot are caused by gear-to-gear interactions?

All the gears on the pivot mech are from REV, and they have a tighter hex bore than other hex gears. During assembly, we shimmed all the gears using tape to ensure a tight press fit on the hex shaft. Additionally, each Kraken pinion was green-labeled on its spline-xs shaft. Routine checking and tightening of the #35 chain when needed helped minimize backlash on our arm.

posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked: Sure! Below is a section view with all of the labeled components. A screenshot 2025-04-21 at 6.21.29 PM shows the labeled parts, including a WCP rubber friction brake on an 8mm lead screw. This brake is driven into a lathe-down aluminum hex hub attached to a gear for pivoting, minimizing the required force early in the reduction process. Additionally, a GIF titled "Screen Recording Apr 21 2025" illustrates the small angle movement and interference between the rubber pad and hex hub (shown in red). The free-spinning motor aids in field setup and manual positioning. Let me know if you’d like more information.

link_counts.title: Most ridiculous use of a CIM-class motor

posts.name: Samjackjoetedpaulbill
posts.cooked: Congratulations on your incredible run in your division and on Einstein—you were a very valuable member of the Daly alliance!

posts.name: Eli Uva
posts.cooked: It was awesome seeing you guys win your division on Daly! You guys built an amazing robot and formed an incredible team.

posts.name: Gabriel McMahon
posts.cooked: Thank you! If there was one thing that you would have designed differently from the start or still want to tweak, what would it be?
